facts.text: Decree against three defendants resident of Parbhani district in former State of Hyderabad.

facts.text: Appellant applied for leave to defend before decree was passed.

facts.text: Respondent took out execution on June 18, 1954 in Court of District Judge, Bhir.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took out execution on June 18, 1954 in the Court of the District Judge, Bhir, to which objection was taken by the appellant,

facts.text: Appellant objected to execution on ground that he had not submitted to jurisdiction of Bombay High Court, which was a foreign court.

facts.text: Appeal taken to High Court against order overruling objection.

facts.text: High Court held on July 29, 1958 that appellant had submitted to jurisdiction of Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Present appeal brought against order dated October 24, 1958 on certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: It is against that order that the appeal has been brought on the certificate of the High Court under Art. 133 1  c . A person who appears in obedience
under Art. 133 1   e  of the Constitution against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay. The appellant was the judgement-debtor and the decree-holder is the respondent.

concepts.unlisted_description: High Court certificate for appeal to Supreme Court in civil matters

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 133 1  c . A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is number companypellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court Shaikh Atham Sahib v. Davud Sahib 1 .

concepts.unlisted_description: High Court certificate for appeal to Supreme Court in civil matters

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent appeal against that judgment was dismissed in limine on October 24, 1958. It is against that order that the appeal has been brought on the certificate of the High Court under Art. 133 1  c .

concepts.interpretation: Decree of a foreign court not executable unless submission to jurisdiction
concepts.unlisted_description: Decree passed by a foreign court, executability depends on submission

anchor.surface_text: A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is number companypellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court Shaikh Atham Sahib v. Davud Sahib 1 .

concepts.interpretation: Appearance in obedience to process and applying for leave to defend without jurisdictional objection constitutes voluntary submission when not legally compelled to appear
concepts.unlisted_label: Voluntary Submission to Jurisdiction of Foreign Court
concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine holding voluntary appearance and participation without protest as submission (citing Shaikh Atham Sahib v. Davud Sahib)

issues.text: Whether the appellant voluntarily submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court (a foreign court) by applying for leave to defend the suit without objecting to its jurisdiction, thereby rendering the decree executable.

anchor.surface_text: to which objection was taken by the appellant, inter alia, on the ground that he had number submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court which was a foreign companyrt and therefore the decree was a foreign decree and companyld number be executed in the Court at Bhir. This objection was overruled.

issues.text: Whether appearance in obedience to process of a foreign court and applying for leave to defend without jurisdictional objection constitutes voluntary submission to jurisdiction when not compellable by law.

anchor.surface_text: A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is number companypellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court Shaikh Atham Sahib v. Davud Sahib 1 .

arguments.claim: The appellant had not submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court which was a foreign court and therefore the decree was a foreign decree and could not be executed in the Court at Bhir

anchor.surface_text: to which objection was taken by the appellant, inter alia, on the ground that he had number submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court which was a foreign companyrt and therefore the decree was a foreign decree and companyld number be executed i

arguments.court_reasoning: Court held that appearance in obedience to process and applying for leave to defend without jurisdictional objection constitutes voluntary submission when not compellable, citing precedent

arguments.claim: The appellant had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court

anchor.surface_text: Against that order appeal was taken to the High Court and it was held by that Court on July 29, 1958 that the appellant had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court affirmed by applying precedent on voluntary submission through appearance and seeking leave to defend without objection

arguments.claim: A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is number companypellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court

anchor.surface_text: A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is number companypellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court Shaikh Atham Sahib v. Davud Sahib 1 .

holdings.text: A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is number companypellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court

anchor.surface_text: A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is number companypellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court Shaik

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court applies and follows precedent from Shaikh Atham Sahib v. Davud Sahib that appearance in obedience to process and seeking leave to defend without jurisdictional objection equals voluntary submission when not legally compelled

holdings.text: The appellant had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court by appearing and applying for leave to defend without objecting to jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Against that order appeal was taken to the High Court and it was held by that Court on July 29, 1958 that the appellant had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court and the appeal was therefore dismissed and the order of the Executing Court upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court upholds High Court finding of submission based on facts of appearance and conditional leave application without jurisdictional challenge, applying doctrine of voluntary submission
